Guerrero-Ruiz a c a Department of Inorganic Chemistry and Technical Chemistry, UNED, Madrid, Spain Department of Inorganic Chemistry and Technical Chemistry UNED Madrid Spain b Institute of Catalysis and Petrochemistry, CSIC, Madrid, Spain Institute of Catalysis and Petrochemistry CSIC Madrid Spain c Grupo de Diseño y Aplicación de Catalizadores Heterogéneos, Unidad Asociada UNED-CSIC (ICP), Spain Grupo de Diseño y Aplicación de Catalizadores Heterogéneos Unidad Asociada UNED-CSIC (ICP) Spain ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Catalysis and Petrochemistry, CSIC, Madrid, Spain. Institute of Catalysis and Petrochemistry CSIC Madrid Spain Graphical abstract The physicochemical and catalytic properties of bimetallic AgCu catalysts and their monometallic counterparts supported on a high surface area graphite have been comparatively evaluated in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction, performed in a continuous-flow reactor. While Cu was incorporated by the incipient wetness impregnation technique, for Ag catalysts two synthesis procedures were explored: incipient wetness impregnation and adsorption of Tollens’ reagent. The catalysts prepared by wetness impregnation exhibited higher metal dispersion, being improved for the bimetallic catalysts in comparison with the monometallic counterparts. The results obtained in the catalytic tests revealed that Cu catalysts is nearly two orders of magnitude more active than Ag catalyst in the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol on either a turnover frequency or a weight basis, but at the same time both catalysts were 100% selective to acetaldehyde. Whereas selectivity was not affected by the bimetallic composition, there was a substantial decrease in the reaction rate among the bimetallic catalysts as the Cu/Ag ratio diminished, due to blockage of copper surface active sites by silver. Both silver and copper, and the bimetallic catalysts, suffered from deactivation at 523 K, caused by blocking of active sites by adsorbed hydrocarbons on the catalyst surface (fouling). Carbonaceous deposits were removed through a thermal treatment under H2 flow, which allowed the total recovery of the initial catalytic activity. Keywords Bimetallic catalysts Alcohol dehydrogenation Fouling Catalyst reactivation 1 Introduction Although copper and silver exhibit similar chemical and physical properties as both are located in the same group of the periodic table, their catalytic properties are quite different. While copper catalysts are widely used in selective dehydrogenation [1–5] and also in hydrogenation reactions [6–8], silver is considered one of the most efficient catalysts in selective oxidation reactions [9–14] due to its ability in the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules. Although to a much lesser extent, Ag has been also applied as a dehydrogenation catalyst in non-oxidative conditions [15–17]. Ag catalysts have been furthermore employed in a wide variety of reactions such as NOx reduction [18], epoxidation of alkenes [19], and reduction of nitrophenol [20]. As above mentioned, copper is the most popular inexpensive metal used for the selective dehydrogenation of alcohols applied in industry, due to its ability to dehydrogenate the alcohol without splitting the CC bond of the produced aldehyde. Nevertheless, one of the main disadvantages for its application as catalyst is said to be the rapid deactivation caused by a loss of active surface due to the high propensity of copper to sintering [21], owing to its low Tamman temperature (678 K) [22]. Thus different strategies have been proposed to improve the catalytic performance of these traditional Cu supported catalysts. In this way, trying to increase the metal dispersion and to avoid the migration and coalescence of Cu particles during reaction conditions, different supports such as silica, zirconia or alumina, and also copper chromite [23,24], have been deeply explored. Silica has been claimed to be very appropriate as catalyst support in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction, being the bonds SiOCu responsible for maintaining the stability of copper [25,26]. Nonetheless, the acid and/or basic sites such as the surface hydroxyl groups of these conventional supports tend to catalyze secondary reactions generating acid catalyzed byproducts (ethylene, diethyl ether) or condensation products (ethyl acetate, butanol, etc) [27]. Aiming to overcome this drawback, carbon materials have been claimed to be very appropriate for this reaction as offer a chemically inert surface [28], leading to selectivities close to 100% to the dehydrogenation product, as we demonstrated in our former work [29]. Apart from the use of a suitable support, recent research has also focused on the synthesis of multicomponent Cu catalysts in order to mitigate particle sintering. It is said that the addition of a second metal may not only increase catalytic activity and catalyst lifetime, but also could enable reduction of the Cu precursor to metallic Cu. Furthermore, it is known that bimetallic catalysts cannot only finely modify the catalytic properties of metals but also can provide synergistic effects. For example, bimetallic NiCu catalysts have been found to be more active and stable for the ethanol steam reforming reaction [30,31] than monometallic Cu catalyst. Several papers have been published in the case of bimetallic catalyst composed of Cu and Ag with promising results. Silver has a higher reduction potential than copper, hence, it can modify copper electronic properties [32] when they constitute a bimetallic structure. Indeed, bimetallic systems composed of Cu and Ag have been successfully applied in oxidation reactions of alcohols. It has been reported that the stability has notably improved in comparison with the copper monometallic [33], and also it is said that the presence of Ag avoids oxidation of Cu. Liu et al. [34] observed a synergistic effect between Ag and Cu in the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate, which reflected a remarkably enhanced turnover frequency as well as an increase in the stability with time due to the strong interaction between Cu and Ag. Also this bimetallic system has been also effectively employed in other reactions such as epoxidation of ethylene [35] and the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [36]. Coming back to the field of dehydrogenation reactions of alcohols, the catalytic performance of bimetallic catalysts in these reactions has been poorly explored and is not well understood. In this line, it has been reported that the isopropanol dehydrogenation rate was higher for bimetallic Ru-Rh and Ru-Pt than the three monometallic catalysts [37]. This enhanced performance was endorsed to a synergistic effect between the two metals, leading to an improved hydrogen removal pathway from Ru surface atoms to Pt or Rh atoms via spillover mechanism. Rioux and Vannice [38] studied the dehydrogenation of isopropanol over bimetallic Cu-Pt and found out that bimetallic Cu-Pt catalysts were less active, expressed either as activity per gram or as turnover frequency (TOF), than their monometallic counterparts, though no changes in selectivity values were observed. They attributed this behavior to an electronic effect and/or to the fact that the rate determining step for both monometallic catalysts, Cu and Pt, is the same. To our knowledge, very little has been published concerning the dehydrogenation of ethanol over bimetallic catalysts. Recently Shan et al. [39] showed that a small addition of Ni into Cu, forming highly diluted NiCu alloys, not only improves the stability but also increases the catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation of ethanol into acetaldehyde. These researchers attributed the improvement in the long-term stability of the catalysts to the stabilization of Cu against sintering. Ponomavera et al. [40] studied that reaction over bimetallic CuCo catalysts, which were about 1.5 times more active than the monometallic Cu, measured in terms of gram of metal. No reference about stability was done in their study. In this work, we comparatively study the dehydrogenation of ethanol, in a fixed bed reactor, over Ag, Cu and bimetallic AgCu catalysts. This reaction is also interesting from a sustainable point of view as ethanol is being considered not only a biofuel but also a platform molecule for the production of high added value products [41]. Among the processes for bioethanol valorization, the dehydrogenation of bioethanol to acetaldehyde is contemplated as a more sustainable and environmental friendly alternative to the industrial route currently used Wacker process (ethylene oxidation) [42]. Acetaldehyde is an important intermediate in the synthesis of several organic acids and of condensation products. In the present study we firstly comparatively evaluate the catalytic performance of Cu and Ag catalysts, and then we focus on the study of the effect of the Ag addition into Cu catalysts, in terms of catalytic activity, stability and regeneration of the catalyst. Furthermore, to the best of our knowledge, very little has been published on the deactivation causes as well as on the regeneration process for catalysts applied in this reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The monometallic catalysts, 5Cu/HSAG and 5Ag/HSAG, were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation using Cu(NO3)23H2O and Ag(NO3) as metal precursors, respectively. The synthesis of the catalysts was performed by adding a water solution at pH = 1 prepared from HNO3 to the as-received commercial high surface area graphite provided by Timcal (HSAG, SBET = 300 m2 g−1). For comparison purposes, two other Ag catalysts were prepared following different procedures. One of them, labelled as Agnatural pH/HSAG, was synthesized by means of the same procedure as just described with the exception that just an aqueous solution was employed without altering the natural pH. The other one, 5AgTll/HSAG, was prepared by the adsorption on aqueous solution of the complex Ag(NH3)2NO3, known as the Tollens’ reagent, following the process described elsewhere [43,44]. Briefly, an AgNO3 aqueous solution was initially prepared by dissolving 0.165 g of AgNO3 in 50 mL of distilled water. Then 2 mL of NaOH solution (0.5 N) was added dropwise leading to the formation of a brown precipitate (Ag2O). Afterwards, 2.2 mL of NH4OH (10 wt.%) was added to the mixture in order to dissolve the precipitate due to the formation of Ag(NH3)+ 2 complexes. Thereafter 50 mL of distilled water and 25 mL of ethanol were added, together with 2 g of HSAG, and the aqueous dispersion was maintained under stirring at 313 K for 2 h. Finally, the as-prepared 5AgTll/HSAG was separated from the solution by filtration. The bimetallic Ag-Cu catalysts, with three different Cu/Ag ratios (6.8; 2.5; 1.1 for 1Ag4Cu, 2Ag3Cu, 3Ag2Cu, respectively) were prepared by co-impregnation of the two metal precursors, Cu(NO3)23H2O and Ag(NO3), respectively, following the same procedure as that for the monometallic counterparts. All the catalysts have a total nominal metallic content of 5 wt.%. For the used nomenclature, the number before the atomic symbol refers to the nominal weight percent of each metal. After the synthesis stage, the samples were dried at room temperature and stored in a desiccator. Ag samples were protected from light. Previously to the characterization and the catalytic tests, the samples were reduced employing 50 mL/min of H2/He (10:90%) at 573 K for 1 h (rate 5 K/min). 2.2 Catalysts characterization Nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurement was performed at 77 K using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 micromeritics system. Before the measurement, the catalysts were outgassed in vacuum at 423 K for 12 h. The Brunauer– Emmett–Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface areas. The total pore volumes (Vt) were estimated from the adsorbed amount at a relative pressure P/P0 of 0.97. The average pore diameter of the supports was determined by the BJH method (desorption branch). XRD patterns were obtained on a Polycristal X’Pert Pro PANalytical diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 0.1544 nm) operating at 45 kV and 40 mA. For each sample, Bragg’s angles between 4° and 90° were scanned at a rate of 0.04 deg/sec. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in an SDT Q 600 apparatus on both the impregnated and reduced samples, under inert atmosphere (He 100 mL/min) and air atmosphere (100 mL/min), respectively. Furthermore, TG analysis were also performed on spent catalysts in order to study the evolution of desorbed products. In this case, the TGA equipment was coupled with a quadruple mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Vacuum OmnistarTM GSD 301). For this purpose, the following mass fragments were recorded taking into account the corresponding literature [45]: H2 (m/z = 2), CO (m/z = 28 and 16), CO2 (m/z = 44), H2O (m/z = 18 and 17), ethanol (m/z = 31, 29, 45 and 27), acetaldehyde (m/z = 29, 44, 43 and 15), diethyl ether (m/z = 31, 59, 74 and 45), ethylene (m/z = 28, 27 and 26), butene (m/z = 41 and 56), crotonaldehyde (m/z = 41, 39, 70 and 69), butanal (m/z = 44, 43, 72, 41, 27 and 29), ethyl acetate (m/z = 43), and 2-butenol (m/z = 57 and 29). In order to obtain information on the morphological characteristics such as shape and size of metal crystallites on the different supports, the reduced catalysts were subjected to a detailed Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) study. TEM micrographs were obtained on a JEOL 2100 F electron microscope operated at 200 kV and equipped with an Energy-Dispersive X-Ray detector (EDX). The samples were milled and suspended in ethanol by ultrasonic treatment and a drop of the fine suspension was placed on a carbon-coated nickel grid to be loaded into the microscope. The mean diameter of metallic particles (d) was calculated, based on a minimum of 400 particles, using the following formula: d=∑nidi 3/∑nidi 2, being ni the number of particles with a diameter of di. The Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) was done using a spot size of 1 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected with an SPECS GmbH with UHV system, energy analyzer PHOIBOS 150 9MCD under non-monochromatic X-ray source of Al (200 W, 1486.71 eV). Prior to the analysis, each sample was pressed into a small pellet of 10 mm diameter, placed in the sample holder and degassed in the chamber for 24 h to achieve a dynamic vacuum below 10−10 mbar. The spectral data for each sample were analyzed using CASA XPS software. The binding energy (BE) was referenced to the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. The equipment error in the energy determinations is less than 0.01 eV. The resulting spectra were deconvoluted and fitted to a mix of Gaussian and Lorentzian curves. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic conversion of ethanol was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a differential reactor. In each test, a known mass of catalyst (particle sizes between 0.3 and 0.5 mm) diluted in silicon carbide was loaded in a glass tube (9 mm id) that served as a fixed-bed, continuous flow reactor. The mass of catalyst (15–500 mg) was adjusted in each case to work at the same conversion level close to differential conditions (about 10%). Before the reaction tests, the catalysts were reduced in situ with a 10 vol.% H2/He mixture (50 mL/min) at 573 K for 1 h. 5 μL/min of ethanol (99.8% purity) were diluted in 25 mL/min of helium and passed through the catalytic bed. At regular time intervals the reaction products were analyzed in a gas chromatograph (GC) apparatus, equipped with both TCD and FID detectors. This analysis system is directly coupled to the reactor exit. The identification of reaction products was achieved bearing in mind the retention times of pure reference standards. Conversion (XEtOH) and selectivities (Si) were estimated employing the following equations: X E t O H % = F E O - F E F F E O · 100 S i % = n i F i Σ i n i F i · 100 where F EO represents the molar flow of ethanol fed to the reactor, F EF is the ethanol molar flow at the reactor exit, F i is the molar flow of the product i and ni the number of carbon atoms of the product i. The catalytic activity (A) was defined as: A μ m o l E t O H g ∙ s = X E t O H % 100 · F E O μ m o l s W g Where W is the mass of catalyst employed. The activity was then normalized per mole of surface metal species, to obtain the turn over frequency (TOF). For this, the number of active sites exposed to reactants at the surface of the catalyst was calculated from the dispersion (D) obtained using the average particle size measured from TEM. Assuming the spherical shape of particles, according to literature [46] the dispersion of Cu is calculated as: DCu = 1.1/d. In the case of Ag, it has been theoretically estimated bearing in mind that silver has a lattice constant for the fcc structure of a0 = 0,4086 nm [47], and following the calculations described in literature [48] the dispersion degree can be obtained as DAg = 1.16/d. All the catalytic tests were replicated at least twice to confirm the reproducibility. The absence of limitations of matter transfer was verified by working with other catalyst particles sizes (<0.3 mm) and working with the double mass of catalyst. The obtained results confirm that the reaction is kinetically controlled under the used conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural features Fig. S1 (Supporting Information) presents the weight loss experimented after heating up the samples 5Cu/HSAG, 5Ag/HSAG, 1Ag4Cu/HSAG and HSAG, under inert atmosphere. In this case, the samples have been just impregnated, without any further reduction treatment. Also the thermogravimetric profile of HSAG corresponds to the support impregnated with an acidic solution in the same conditions as that of the impregnated samples, in order to have an idea of the quantity of the functional groups incorporated in these synthesis conditions. A significant weight loss was observed until about 373 K, ascribed to the desorption of water. From the HSAG thermogravimetric profile, it can be deduced that the total weight loss due to the adsorbed water as well as oxygenated functional groups is about 5.7%. The derived weight curve of the impregnated samples indicates that the required minimum temperature to decompose the precursor salt is around 473 K, for both Cu and Ag precursors. Fig. S2 offers the thermogravimetric profile in air atmosphere of all prepared catalysts after the reduction process at 573 K. Firstly, these thermograms confirm that the precursor salt is totally decomposed after the activation process, and the presence of water or functional groups in the reduced catalyst is negligible as no loss weight is detected until the support begins to burn out. Secondly, this process provides information about the total metal content as the residual mass corresponds to the metal oxide in the case of copper catalysts and the reduced metal in the case of Ag. As observed in Table S1, these values are very similar to the nominal ones. The detailed structural parameters of the commercial HSAG support and the catalysts are listed in Table 1 and the corresponding nitrogen adsorption isotherms are presented in Fig. S3. As observed, they are quite similar and are classified as IV characteristic of mesoporous materials, with hysteresis of type H3 according to IUPAC classification. The specific surface area of HSAG support (302 m2 g−1) is comprised mainly of its external surface area, which is characteristic of a material of plate-like particle such as the HSAG. The total pore volume (VT), originated mainly by the interparticle spaces, resulted to be 0.40 cm3 g−1. After coating with metal nanoparticles (NPs), noteworthy differences were found among the metallic catalysts. While the introduction of Ag into the HSAG structure leads to a very low modification in the textural properties of HSAG, the incorporation of Cu NPs in either monometallic or bimetallic catalysts, caused a noticeable loss of porosity, which is mainly reflected in the decrease of the BET surface area (Table 1). This indicates that copper NPs partially block mesopores, unlike Ag nanoparticles, which seem not to modify significantly the surface textural properties of HSAG. Note also that the number of metallic atoms covering the support is quite higher in the case of Cu than that of Ag (molecular weight of copper is near a half of the Ag one). In Fig. 1 the X-ray diffraction patterns of the Ag just-impregnated samples using water solution at natural and acidic pH (Fig. 1a) and the reduced Ag catalysts prepared from different methods (Fig. 1b) are depicted. The diffractogram of the HSAG exhibited the characteristic diffraction pattern of graphitic materials, with a pronounced peak at about 2Ɵ = 26°, due to the (002) graphitic basal plane reflection. No changes in the graphitic crystalline structure were detected in any catalyst after the incorporation of the metallic phases. However, significant differences were observed in the X-ray diffraction pattern of the impregnated samples depending on the solvent employed to dissolve the metal precursor Ag(NO)3 (Fig. 1a). It should be noted that, like copper, silver is highly prone to sintering due to its low Tamman temperature (617 K) [22]. Furthermore, it presents a very low potential reduction. Therefore, considerable efforts have been described in literature aiming to synthesize supported silver NPs with the required sizes. Moreover, the synthesis of Ag catalysts over carbon materials is a particular complex process due to the high reducibility of Ag in contact with a reductant material such as carbon. Hence, the impregnation of HSAG with a solution of AgNO3 in distilled water (Agnatural pH/HSAG) gave rise to the instant reduction of silver. This was easily observable as the carbonaceous surface turned from black to light grey as it was drying after putting in contact with the impregnation solution, which indicated that Ag+ was prematurely reduced to metallic Ag. Graphitic layers constituents of this support, which are enriched in ᴨ-electrons, would behave as Lewis base donating electrons and thus promoting silver reduction. Similar findings have been reported in literature in silver adsorption studies over activated carbon when the pH is not low enough [49]. The formation of large crystals of silver was confirmed by the presence of various intense peaks corresponding to reflection planes of the fcc crystalline structure of silver (JCPDS 4-783) (Fig. 1a). After applying Scherrer equation to the line broadening of (111) diffraction peak (2Ɵ = 38.4°), the average size of Ag crystallites in this fresh catalyst resulted to be 52 nm. In contrast, when Ag(NO)3 is dissolved in an oxidant solution employing HNO3 for doing the impregnations no peaks characteristics of crystalline phases were detected in the X-ray diffraction pattern (5AgpH=1/HSAG, Fig. 1a). This confirmed that the acid solution successfully remained the Ag in the oxidized state, avoiding its reduction and further agglomeration. After the reduction process at 573 K of this impregnated sample, some broad and low intense characteristics peaks of silver appeared (5Ag/HSAG, Fig. 1b). However, when the synthesis of silver catalyst was done by the adorption of Tollen’s reagent, the X-ray diffraction pattern of the catalyst after the reduction step exhibited narrow and high intense peaks (Fig. 1b), due to the presence of metallic crystals up to 55 nm in size, as calculated by applying Scherrer formula (Table 1). These results are in the same line as those reported by Kyriakidou et al. [43]. They observed that the adsorption of diaminne complex on an oxidized carbon support, at any pH, gave rise to larger particles (20 nm), in comparison with those formed on silica, alumina or zirconia supports. On the contrary, T. Ji et al. [44] successfully controlled the Ag particle size, which resulted to be lower than 5 nm and with a narrow particle size distribution. These latter researchers attributed this high metal dispersion to the high specific area of the support and to the presence of oxygen functional groups which act as nucleation points for crystal growth. Fig. 2 presents the X-ray diffraction patterns of all the bimetallic catalysts, along with their monometallic counterparts, prepared by the wetness impregnation method and reduced at 573 K. The catalyst 5Cu/HSAG exhibited a very weak and broad peak at 2Ɵ = 36,4°, indicative of the crystalline structure of Cu2O (JCPDS 01-078-2076). By applying Scherrer equation, the average particle size was 3.9 nm, which is in the limit of the range application of this formula. It is interesting to note that, for bimetallic catalysts, indicative peaks of crystalline phases were poorly detected, which suggests that bimetallic NPs were highly dispersed. 3.2 Surface properties Fig.3 shows some representative TEM images of the monometallic catalysts, along with their corresponding histograms that represent the particle sizes distribution. Additional TEM images can be found in the Supporting Information (Fig. S4). Average particles sizes were obtained after counting at least 400 particles for each sample and are collected in Table 1. On one hand, it is worth mentioning that mean crystallite size of 5Cu/HSAG, measured either by TEM (5.6 nm) or XRD (˜4 nm) does not differ significantly (Table 1). Even though this catalyst exhibited a wide particle size distribution (with metallic nanoparticles ranging from 2 up to 10 nm), given the calculated average particle diameter, it can be stated that our synthesis procedure–using an oxidant such as HNO3 for the impregnation–seems to be quite appropriate for the preparation of both silver and copper catalysts. Note that in our previous work [29], employing a very similar material (HSAG500) and dissolving the metallic precursor in distilled water at natural pH, the Cu crystallite size resulted to be rather higher (10 nm). Furthermore, the metallic dispersion achieved in this work is fairly greater than that reported for other carbon-supported copper catalysts described in literature [28,46,50,51]. On the other hand, the mean crystallite size of 5Ag/HSAG estimated by TEM (7.4 nm) resulted to be slightly lower than that estimated by XRD (8.2 nm). As observed in its corresponding histogram, this sample exhibits a very wide particle size distribution; where near 40% of particles are lower than 4 nm, not detectable by XRD. The achieved dispersion here obtained is in the same range than that reported in literature for Ag NPs on metal oxides, for example, over SiO2 [52] or Al2O3 [53], using also the preparation method of incipient wetness impregnation. As for the bimetallic catalysts, the addition of Ag for all the loading levels, gave rise to a decrease of the average crystallite size in comparison with the monometallic counterparts, in agreement with earlier works [57]. For example, it is interesting to note that mean size decreased from 5.6 nm in 5Cu/HSAG to 3.9 nm in 1Ag4Cu/HSAG (Fig. 4 ), which is compatible with the absence of distinctive peaks of metallic crystalline phases in the X-ray pattern of this sample (Fig.2). Furthermore, the particle size distribution obtained is significantly narrower than those exhibited by their monometallic counterparts, especially in comparison with the silver monometallic sample (Fig. 3). In Fig. 5 and S4 representative STEM images with an EDX elemental mapping of the bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG and 3Ag2Cu/HSAG catalysts, respectively, are shown. As observed, Ag NPs (blue) are homogeneously distributed among the copper NPs (red), indicating the presence of Ag in the neighborhood of Cu NPs, inhibiting their agglomeration. Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra of the catalysts. The Cu 2p core level spectrum (Fig. 6a) exhibits two major peaks centered at binding energies of 933.1 and 952.7 eV, attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 doublets characteristic of copper, respectively. The 2p3/2 peak was deconvoluted into two different contributions which can be attributed to Cu(II) species at 934.7 eV and Cu(0)/Cu(I) species at 932.7 eV. The shake-up peaks at 943.5 and 962.8 eV further confirmed the presence of Cu(II) species [54].The existence of Cu(II) could be due to partial re-oxidation on the surface of Cu when exposed to an oxidizing environment such as the air, given that copper is easily oxidized. Concerning the monometallic Ag catalysts, as reported in the literature [55], XPS peaks at 368.4 eV and 374.4 eV are typical of metallic Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2, respectively (Fig. 6b, Table 2 ). Moreover, the Ag 3d5/2 BE values of Ag2O and AgO range from 367.6 to 367.7 and 367.2 to 367.4 eV, respectively. These values are in contrast to the typical positive core level BE shifts of metal cations in ionic materials. Unlike the case of copper, no oxidized silver was found in our samples; note that the standard reduction potential of Cu°/Cu2+ (0.34 V) is much lower than that of silver (0.80 V) [56]. Fig. 6c) and 6d) offers the Cu 2p and the 3dAg core level spectra, respectively, of the bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG catalyst and the corresponding binding energies are collected in Table 2. The slight increase of the binding energy value (0.1 eV) observed in both Ag3d5/2 and Cu2p3/2 suggests the possible electronic interaction between Ag and Cu in the 1Ag4Cu bimetallic sample. This is in agreement with other literature findings [57], which is explained as an electron transfer from copper to silver. It is interesting to note that the Cu/Ag atomic ratio in the bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG determined by XPS is 2.2, which is remarkably lower than the corresponding bulk atomic ratio (6.8). This indicates the presence of Ag clusters around the surfaces of Cu NPs. 3.3 Catalytic performance in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction 3.3.1 Catalytic properties Prior to the catalytic tests, the inertness of the reactor, the SiC catalyst diluent as well as the HSAG support (treated with nitric acid), was verified over the temperature range studied. The effect of the temperature in the initial catalytic activity (expressed as transformed mol of ethanol per gram of catalyst and per second) of catalysts prepared by wetness impregnation is represented in Fig. 7 . Catalysts were tested after activation for 1 h at 573 K in H2/He and the mass of catalyst was adjusted in every case to work under isoconversion levels close to differential conditions (XEtOH= ˜15%). 3.3.1.1 Comparison between 5Cu/HSAG and 5Ag/HSAG catalysts Even though both 5Ag/HSAG and 5Cu/HSAG were 100% selective to the dehydrogenation product, acetaldehyde, 5Cu/HSAG was extremely more active than 5Ag/HSAG, being these differences more marked as the temperature increased. At 523 K the initial catalytic activity of 5Cu/HSAG was 15.5 μmol∙s−1 g−1 much higher than that of 5Ag/HSAG (0.27 μmol∙s−1 g−1). Table 3 collects also the intrinsic activity measured as TOF as well as the reaction rate expressed per gram of metallic component at this temperature. Hence, the results obtained in the catalytic test revealed that 5Cu/HSAG is nearly two orders of magnitude more active than 5Ag/HSAG in the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol on either a TOF or a weight basis. Even lower was the catalytic activity of 5AgTll/HSAG, which can be explained due to the larger particle size of this catalyst (Table 3), which means a lower exposed metallic surface area. Thus the dehydrogenation properties of Ag catalysts in non-oxidative atmosphere are quite limited, in our experimental conditions. As already mentioned in the introduction section, silver catalysts are widely used in alcohol oxidation reactions. For example, Ag/hydroxyapatite exhibited a TOF of 1.38 s−1 [58] in the ethanol oxidation at 523 K, clearly superior to the activity displayed in the non-oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol obtained in this work. However, the main drawback of oxidative dehydrogenations is the low selectivity to the dehydrogenation product [10–14,59,60] in comparison with the non-oxidative dehydrogenation; for example, acetaldehyde selectivity in oxidative atmosphere was only about 70% in [59] and 85% in [60]. Arrhenius plots are represented in Figure S6. The values of the activation energies are collected in Table 3. As observed, they are rather similar, which suggests that the reaction proceeds through the same mechanism for both 5Cu/HSAG and 5Ag/HSAG catalysts. These apparent activation energies are similar to those previously reported for this reaction [26]. 3.3.1.2 Effect of silver addition into copper catalysts Like their monometallic Ag or Cu counterparts, all bimetallic catalysts were 100% selective for acetaldehyde, the dehydrogenation product. Whereas selectivity was not affected by the bimetallic composition, there was significant variability in the reaction rate among the monometallic and bimetallic catalysts, in all the temperature range (Fig.7, Table 3). It is observed that the lower the copper content is, the lower the catalytic activity displayed by the catalyst (1Ag4Cu/HSAG > 2Ag3Cu/HSAG > 3Ag2Cu/HSAG). It should be noted that, despite the fact that bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG has a Cu content close to its monometallic counterpart, its catalytic activity per metal content was quite lower (Table 3). This suggests the presence of Ag blocks the surface active sites of Cu, inhibiting their catalytic activity, which indicates also that both metals are closely contacted although no synergistic effect in the catalytic activity is detected. This finding is in agreement with the decrease of the surface atomic Cu/Ag ratio determined by XPS analysis, which indicated a partial blockage of Cu by Ag. This loss of catalytic activity in the ethanol dehydrogenation has been also reported by Freitas and co-workers [61], when the Ag content was gradually increased in bimetallic systems AgCu/ZrO2. However, they also observed changes in the product distribution; the increase in Ag content gave rise to an increment in the selectivity to ethyl acetate at expense of acetaldehyde. In our work, we did not detect changes in the product distribution among the series of tested catalysts, since the only detected product was acetaldehyde in every case. Note that the support plays an important role in the synthesis of this secondary product, which reaction mechanism involves the presence of strong acidic sites existing in zirconia but not in our HSAG. In contrast, Tripathi and co-workers [62] reported an improvement in the catalytic activity and the stability in the ethanol dehydrogenation towards butadiene by the bimetallic CuAg/MgO-SiO2 catalyst in comparison with the monometallic counterparts. They attributed this enhancement to an improvement of the metal dispersion and/or synergistic electronic effect between both metals, although they did not provide any data to support this statement. Also Totong et al. [63] reported that the bimetallic catalyst AgCu/SiO2 exhibited a higher performance in the ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde at 573 K in comparison with the monometallic counterparts, which is not in agreement with our results. Nonetheless, in their work they did neither explain the causes for this enhanced catalytic performance of the bimetallic system, nor the induced support effects. Concerning the effect of the addition of Ag to Cu on the activation energy, no differences in these values were detected in comparison to the monometallic counterparts (Table 3), suggesting the dehydrogenation reaction proceeds in the same manner. This further confirms that the addition of Ag to Cu does not have any positive impact in the reactivity of Cu. 3.3.2 Deactivation and regeneration studies Catalyst stability as a function of time-on-stream was investigated and the results are represented in Fig. 8 . As mentioned in the introduction section, while various reports can be found in literature showing the stability of copper catalysts in the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol, most of them employing Cu-SiO2 [26] or Cu-chromite systems [24], there are still several cases reporting that copper catalysts suffered from noticeable deactivation [1,64,65]. In our previous work [29] we found that copper supported on HSAG500 was quite stable during 5 h at the low temperature of 453 K (W/FA0 = 13.5 g h·mol−1). Conversely, in this current work (W/FA0 = 3.12 g h·mol−1) when the temperature increased up to 523 K we detected a substantial deactivation for Cu catalyst after 8 h on stream (catalytic activity decrease about 35%). The sample 5Ag /HSAG also exhibited a deactivation rate of about 25%, as shown in Fig. 8. Likewise, the bimetallic system 1Ag4Cu/HSAG displayed a comparable deactivation profile to their monometallic counterparts. Some studies [34] have shown that Ag and Cu catalysts show unsatisfactory thermal stability due to metallic particle aggregation which is remarkably improved by the bimetallic system CuAg because it is said that Ag clusters onto the surfaces of copper restrain the migration of Cu NPs. This could be displayed if sintering would be the only cause for deactivation. We focused our study on the causes of deactivation in order to distinguish if they were related to coke deposition or sintering phenomena. Moreover, very little has been published about the reactivation processes of copper catalysts in the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol [1]. Whereas sintering is usually irreversible, the catalyst decay due to carbon or coke formation is easily reversed through combustion or thermal treatment with hydrogen [66]. Nonetheless, it must be considered that removal of the carbon in presence of hydrogen at high temperatures could produce the metal sintering, but if the thermal treatment is carried out under either oxygen or air flow, combustion of the support HSAG could take place. Hence, in order to determine if the observed deactivation is reversible or not, we studied a regeneration procedure based on a treatment in pure H2 at 573 K for 1 h. Afterwards the regenerated catalysts were tested in the gas-phase ethanol dehydrogenation at 523 K, at the same conditions than those employed with the fresh ones. As observed in Fig. 8, this regeneration process was successfully applied and the recovery of the initial activity took place for both monometallic catalysts, 5Cu/HSAG and 5Ag/HSAG, and the bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG. This suggests that fouling is the main cause of deactivation in our catalytic conditions. Furthermore, this thermal treatment did not cause any significant modification of the nature of the active sites, since the same initial conversion level was obtained after it. It is worth mentioning that most of the referred literature of dehydrogenation reactions of alcohols indicates that copper catalyst deactivation are related to sintering process [39,51,65,67,68], or both to coke deposition and sintering [69,70]. However, XRD profiles (Fig. S7) of the reduced and used catalysts were very similar, which suggests that the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction did not cause any significant change on the crystalline phases; neither the support nor the copper metallic NPs. To further exclude a loss of activity caused by metal sintering mechanism, the spent monometallic catalysts were studied in detail by TEM, and the corresponding micrographs and histograms are depicted in Fig. 3 and Fig S8. The comparable mean diameters obtained for the fresh (5.6 nm) and the spent 5Cu/HSAG (5.7 nm), confirms that sintering was not involved in the deactivation mechanism of the copper catalyst. A quite curious scenario is presented with the 5Ag/HSAG catalyst. As observed by XRD (Fig. S7), the diffraction peak at 38.4 degrees became slightly thinner (by applying Scherrer equation this corresponds to an increase in the crystallite size from 8.2 up to 9.7 nm) and TEM images reveal that average particle size has increased up to 11 nm in the spent catalyst. Since the initial catalytic activity is totally recovered after the regeneration treatment, we speculate that sintering of Ag NPs could take place at very early stage of the reaction at 523 K, during the first minutes of reaction. Concerning the bimetallic 1Ag4Cu/HSAG, the absence of crystalline peaks in the XRD pattern suggests no sintering was present in the spent catalyst. To further confirm the type of presence of carbonaceous residues deposited on the surface of the spent catalysts, desorption of adsorbed species was followed by TGA-MS on the used monometallic samples. For this, samples were heated until 900 K at a rate of 5 K/min under a 100 mL/min flow of He (TGA) and the desorbed products were followed by mass spectrometry (MS). This experiment was also performed with the fresh catalysts to verify the absence of desorbed products. Fig. 9 a) presents the weight loss experimented due to desorption of the carbon products present in the spent 5Cu/HSAG catalyst while 9b) shows the mass fragments desorbed during this heating process. The TGA-MS of the 5Ag/HSAG is represented in Fig. S9, which resulted to be very similar. Weight loss (5.8% for 5Cu/HSAG and 3.7% for 5Ag/HSAG) is observed at two different temperature ranges: 350–450 K and 550–750 K as can be deduced from the thermogravimetric analysis profile. This temperature values are coincident with the desorbed species detected by mass spectrometry (Fig. 9b and Fig. S9b). In this study, MS results are not presented to scale, and so serve only for qualitative and not quantitative purposes. As can be viewed, the mass fragments corresponding to acetaldehyde (m/z 29) and ethanol (m/z 31) were found until ˜400 K. In the second temperature range, apart from these two compounds, ethylene (m/z 27) and the condensation product crotonaldehyde (m/z 41) were also detected by MS on both used catalysts. This suggests that in the first case acetaldehyde and ethanol could be weakly physisorbed on the surface while in the second temperature range, together with ethylene and crotonaldehyde, they are strongly chemisorbed, probably to the metallic active sites. These two last compounds were not detected among the reaction products during our GC analysis in any case, which suggests they remained anchored on the catalyst surface. Ethylene is formed through a dehydration mechanism [71] while crotonaldehyde is produced through the aldol condensation of acetaldehyde [72]. The formation of these reaction products involves the presence of acidic sites, in our case these would correspond to the oxygen containing acidic groups of the carbon surface. Surprisingly enough, very little has been found in literature attributing the deactivation mechanism of Cu catalysts in dehydrogenation reactions only to deposition of carbonaceous species [73], as here detected. Nonetheless, various studies involving condensation reactions attribute to deposition of carbonaceous residues on the copper surface as the main cause of loss of activity, which can be recovered by means of combustion as well [74,75]. These observations are also consistent with the XPS results, which indicated a remarkable decrease in the surface metallic content of the spent catalysts after reaction (Table 2). 4 Conclusions We have comparatively evaluated the textural, structural, surface and catalytic properties of carbon-supported Cu and Ag catalysts in the ethanol dehydrogenation as well as the effect of Ag addition into Cu catalysts. Firstly, we carried out an initial screening in order to select the most appropriate Ag catalysts synthesis. Metallic nanoparticle dispersion was successfully and simply enhanced by employing an acidic media during the impregnation of the precursor solution on the carbon support. In the bimetallic systems, the presence of Ag reduces the migration of Cu NPs during the reduction process, which is reflected in a higher metallic dispersion in comparison with the monometallic counterparts. As for the catalytic performances, Cu was considerably more active than Ag for ethanol dehydrogenation, on both a gram catalyst and a TOF basis. Though selectivity was not affected by the bimetallic composition, there was a substantial reduction in the catalytic activity among the bimetallic catalysts as the Cu/Ag ratio decreased, despite the higher metal dispersion achieved in these series of catalysts in comparison with the monometallic counterparts. Thus the addition of Ag to Cu catalysts triggered a substantial decrease of the intrinsic activity, likely due to surface coverage of the active Cu species by Ag clusters and the absence of synergistic effect between both metals in this reaction. Our catalytic regeneration treatments, as well as the characterization of the spent catalysts, revealed that deactivation is likely due to carbon species deposition on the catalyst surface (fouling), which may originate from ethanol dehydration or higher hydrocarbons formed in subsequent acetaldehyde condensation reactions. The catalytic activity was totally recovered after a thermal treatment with H2, which further confirms that sintering was not involved in the deactivation mechanism. coredata.dc:description: The physicochemical and catalytic properties of bimetallic AgCu catalysts and their monometallic counterparts supported on a high surface area graphite have been comparatively evaluated in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction, performed in a continuous-flow reactor. While Cu was incorporated by the incipient wetness impregnation technique, for Ag catalysts two synthesis procedures were explored: incipient wetness impregnation and adsorption of Tollens’ reagent. The catalysts prepared by wetness impregnation exhibited higher metal dispersion, being improved for the bimetallic catalysts in comparison with the monometallic counterparts. The results obtained in the catalytic tests revealed that Cu catalysts is nearly two orders of magnitude more active than Ag catalyst in the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol on either a turnover frequency or a weight basis, but at the same time both catalysts were 100% selective to acetaldehyde. Whereas selectivity was not affected by the bimetallic composition, there was a substantial decrease in the reaction rate among the bimetallic catalysts as the Cu/Ag ratio diminished, due to blockage of copper surface active sites by silver. Both silver and copper, and the bimetallic catalysts, suffered from deactivation at 523 K, caused by blocking of active sites by adsorbed hydrocarbons on the catalyst surface (fouling). Carbonaceous deposits were removed through a thermal treatment under H2 flow, which allowed the total recovery of the initial catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Comparative study of Cu, Ag and Ag-Cu catalysts over graphite in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction: Catalytic activity, deactivation and regeneration
